The challenges associated with space travel and exploration are unlike any experienced on Earth. Thus, the Royal Engineers Corps would need to adapt their training and preparation to meet these challenges. Here are some ways they could do so:

1. Zero gravity training: The Royal Engineers would need to adapt their training to prepare for the unique challenges of working in a microgravity environment. Training could include learning how to move and position heavy equipment in a weightless environment, as well as learning how to repair and maintain equipment while floating in space.

2. Radiation exposure training: Astronauts and space travelers are at risk of exposure to high levels of radiation during space travel. The Royal Engineers would need to learn how to minimize this risk by designing and constructing radiation shields to protect equipment and personnel.

3. Extra-vehicular activity (EVA) training: EVA training would be essential, teaching astronauts and engineers how to operate and work in space suits and how to perform repairs and maintenance on spacecraft and buildings on other planets.

4. Long distance communication technology training: One of the significant challenges of space travel is communication delay due to the long distance between Earth and other planets. The Royal Engineers could develop technology and procedures to optimize communication and coordination at these distances.

5. International and inter-agency cooperation: A mission to another planet would require collaboration between multiple international organizations, including governments, space agencies, and private companies. The Royal Engineers would need to develop communication channels and working relationships with these organizations before such international deep-space missions could take place. 

Overall, the Royal Engineers Corps would need to adapt their training and preparation to suit the unique challenges of space travel so that they can play a vital role in disaster relief efforts or space exploration studies in the future.
